title: Interesting font stories
content:
Hi folks!  
I'm a 3rd year design student and my latest assignment is a font showcase that reflects an interesting background or story to a font. Everyone is doing the usual (johnston in the london trasport font...clearview for highway signs etc) but I wanted something different. Ive been trawling books and the net for days but with no luck. Anyone got anything interesting about a font that not many people know?
author: LR

comments.content: You know about the story of Optima, Hermann Zapf and [the 1000 Lire bank note](http://web.archive.org/web/20120720135732/http:/typophile.com/node/15685), right?
That is an interesting story. I hadnt heard it...I'm just learning :-) Thanks for that!

For me, this was very interesting.

[http://autodidakt.se/index.php?page=shabash](http://web.archive.org/web/20120720135732/http:/autodidakt.se/index.php?page=shabash "http://autodidakt.se/index.php?page=shabash")

The story behind the naming of [Mrs Eaves](http://web.archive.org/web/20120720135732/http:/en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mrs_Eaves), nominee for the Almost as Ubiquitous as Times New Roman Award, is amusing and has a bit of type history trivia to it. Though I admit that the Estupido Espezial story is way better.

I used to have that font, but it blew up :^(

Sorry I can't come up with anything more interesting than that.

j a m e s

this is interesting, however

I was trawling through my local cd shop and noticed a cover which caught my eye. It was an album by indy Australian band, The Fauves titled WHEN GOOD TIMES GO GOOD. Upon its sleeve face was a photograph of an old message board (like one from a 50th wedding anniversary or what have you). Whilst the digital rendering was spot on the designer made a fatal error of judgment. Mr Michael Ebbels - although your random kerning amused me, Din (designed in 1994) was not, has not been made into plastic pin on lettering for primitive message boards.

Discuss,
